importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The GPEI will face a 30 percent budget reduction in 2026, impacting the feasibility of polio eradication activities.
A $1.7 billion funding gap is projected through 2029, threatening long-term eradication efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2026 to 2029 marks a critical window of funding shortfall and strategic reallocation within the polio eradication initiative.

keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) faces a $1.7 billion funding gap through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid, especially from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
A 30% budget reduction in 2026 threatens key activities such as vaccination and surveillance in high-risk areas.
The WHO’s director of polio eradication, Jamal Ahmed, emphasizes that eradication remains feasible but requires sustained global commitment.
The GPEI plans to focus resources on high-risk regions like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases were reported in 2025 (36 total cases).
149 cases of vaccine-derived polio have been recorded in 2025, including in Nigeria, highlighting the ongoing risk of vaccine-related transmission.
Strategies such as fractional dosing—using as little as one-fifth of a standard vaccine dose—are being adopted to stretch vaccine supplies while maintaining protection.
The initiative will scale back operations in lower-risk regions unless outbreaks occur, shifting focus to outbreak response.
Despite declines in polio cases since 2024, asymptomatic infections and persistent endemic transmission in Afghanistan and Pakistan remain major challenges.
Global health officials stress that continued vaccination and surveillance are essential to achieving long-term eradication.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), led by the World Health Organization, faces a projected $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced contributions from major donors including the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This financial strain threatens essential activities such as vaccination and surveillance, especially in high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where 36 wild polio cases were reported in 2025. The GPEI is responding by focusing resources on high-risk regions, adopting fractional dosing to stretch vaccine supplies, and collaborating with other health campaigns like measles programmes. Despite the challenges, officials maintain that eradication remains feasible with sustained global commitment, emphasizing the continued importance of vaccination and surveillance to combat both wild and vaccine-derived polio.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
